abstract: Jim Gray, a legendary computer scientist at Microsoft and I.B.M. who disappeared at sea in January 2007, was remembered by hundreds of friends and colleagues Saturday at a day-long tribute at UC Berkeley. An endowed professorship in computer science is being established in his honor.

lead_paragraph: For a half-decade, the San Francisco bureau of The New York Times had a remarkable resource. Just five floors above us were the offices of Microsoft’s Bay Area Research Center and more specifically, Gordon Bell and Jim Gray, two of the world’s legendary computer scientists. I would have coffee with Jim on occasion, and from time to time, we would head down the alleyway to have lunch at Yank Sing, the local dim sum restaurant.

headline.main: A Tribute to Jim Gray: Sometimes Nice Guys Do Finish First

abstract: A series of blog posts on The Huffington Post documents the arrival of the “core competency” mother, who focuses on what she does best and outsources or ignores the rest.
snippet: A series of blog posts on The Huffington Post documents the arrival of the “core competency” mother, who focuses on what she does best and outsources or ignores the rest.
lead_paragraph: According to a series of blog posts on The Huffington Post by Laura Vanderkam, a new type of outsourcing is sweeping dual-income households around the country, and it has a lot to do with sweeping (or not sweeping) the floors. The first post describes what Ms. Vanderkam refers to as the core competency mom, who manages to both have a job and a career by focusing her limited time at home on tasks that give her the most time with her children. As she puts it, “Going on a hike with your teenage children on a Saturday is a better way to show you care than washing their jeans.” As for the floor sweeping — that falls into the category of stuff that is either outsourced or ignored by the core competency mother.

headline.main: Core Competency Mothers

abstract: The China Merchants Bank Company agreed to pay $2.5 billion for control of the Wing Lung Bank of Hong Kong.
snippet: The China Merchants Bank Company agreed to pay $2.5 billion for control of the Wing Lung Bank of Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: The China Merchants Bank Company agreed to pay 19.3 billion Hong Kong dollars ($2.5 billion) for control of the Wing Lung Bank of Hong Kong. Merchants Bank will buy 123.3 billion shares, a 53.1 percent stake, at 156.5 Hong Kong dollars each, from Wing Lung’s chairman, Michael Wu, and his family, the two companies said. China Merchants Bank, based in Shenzhen, will also make a general offer for the rest of Wing Lung’s shares at the same price, valuing the bank at $4.66 billion.

headline.main: China: Bank Makes Hong Kong Acquisition

lead_paragraph: Nissan led a decline in domestic auto sales in May, as higher taxes and fuel costs cut demand. Sales of cars, trucks and buses fell 6.1 percent from a year earlier to 221,377, the Japan Automobile Dealers Association said. The total excludes minicars. Sales at Nissan dropped 11.4 percent to 33,681 vehicles. Toyota’s sales fell 2.8 percent to 105,519 vehicles. Honda sold 26,900 vehicles, a 5.1 percent increase, helped by its revamped Fit compact.

lead_paragraph: THOUGH I’m a fashion designer, I never stuff my luggage with too many items. But like many people, I like to travel with a companion. In my case, it’s my 6-year-old Maltese, Lou Lou. She is a great traveler and loves exploring hotels in Paris and other exotic locales.

headline.main: The Dress Is in Chicago, but Lou Lou’s With Me

abstract: The Supreme Court of Canada said it would hear an appeal from Bell Canada that will very likely determine the fate of a $51.8 billion leveraged buyout of the company.
snippet: The Supreme Court of Canada said it would hear an appeal from Bell Canada that will very likely determine the fate of a $51.8 billion leveraged buyout of the company.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court of Canada said it would hear an appeal from Bell Canada that will very likely determine the fate of a $51.8 billion leveraged buyout of the company. Last month the Court of Appeal of Quebec blocked the buyout, ruling that Bell’s directors had not adequately considered the interests of current bondholders when they agreed to sell the company to a group led by the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan. Since the takeover agreement expires at the end of this month, the court set June 17 as a hearing date.

headline.main: Canada: Supreme Court to Hear Bell Case
headline.print_headline: Canada: Supreme Court To Hear Bell Case

abstract: Comcast will test new devices that will keep track of its users and assemble a blacklist of heavy users. Those on the blacklist will find that all of their online activities may slow down at peak times: from downloading movies to checking e-mail. The company said it would not disclose what sort of usage it takes to get on the black list, how long someone stays on it and if there is any way to get off. Most significantly, Comcast won’t even tell users if they are on the black list.
snippet: Comcast will test new devices that will keep track of its users and assemble a blacklist of heavy users. Those on the blacklist will find that all of their online activities may slow down at peak times: from downloading movies to checking e-mail. ...
lead_paragraph: UPDATE | 6/5 7:40 PM: Comcast objected to the first version of this post, which referred to its method for identifying heavy users as a blacklist. After several conversations, including a call with Mitch Bowling, Comcast’s senior vice president and general manger of its Internet service, I’ve rewritten the headline and a bit of the explanation about how the system being tested works.

headline.main: Comcast Tests a New Bandwidth Throttle

abstract: A conversation with the author Karen Salmansohn, who tackles the big subject of resiliency in a small and punchy new book.
snippet: A conversation with the author Karen Salmansohn, who tackles the big subject of resiliency in a small and punchy new book.
lead_paragraph: Karen Salmansohn has written 29 books and, in the process, created her own mini genre that she calls “self-help for people who wouldn’t be caught dead reading self-help.” The ingredients for a Salmansohn book include bold graphics, advice distilled to digestible nuggets and lots of humor. The levity does not preclude her from tackling weighty subjects, and her latest, “The Bounceback Book,” looks at the psychology behind resiliency and offers 75 tips on how to bounce back after both minor setbacks or major trauma. The tips are brief and punchy (“Walk yourself out of a bad mood,” “If you ask depressing questions, you will 100 percent get depressing answers.” “Change your body. Change your mind.”) and the text that follows offers scientific backing or quotes from the likes of Aristotle, Deepak Chopra or Martin Seligman, a leader in the field of positive psychology.

headline.main: Training the Mind for Resiliency

abstract: A blockade forced General Motors of Canada to close its head office in Oshawa, Ontario.
snippet: A blockade forced General Motors of Canada to close its head office in Oshawa, Ontario.
lead_paragraph: A blockade forced General Motors of Canada to close its head office in Oshawa, Ontario. The Canadian Auto Workers union has charged that a decision by the automaker to close a truck plant in Oshawa violates a labor agreement reached last month. Under the contract's terms, the union contends that G.M. is obliged to find another product to replace the pickup trucks now assembled in the factory, which employees about 2,600 unionized workers. The province of Ontario has also said that G.M. may have to repay hundreds of millions of dollars in incentives it received because of the plant closing. About 100 people blocked roads leading to the head office and demanded a meeting with the company. G.M. has agreed to meet with the union in Detroit on Friday. The union has not indicated when it will lift the blockade.

headline.main: Canada: Union Protests G.M. Plant Closing

Overstock disclosed the inquiry in 2006, saying the S.E.C. was examining its accounting policies and its complaint against research company Gradient Analytics. Patrick Byrne, Overstock’s chief executive, has accused hedge funds, analysts and financial journalists of spreading negative information about his company so that short-sellers can profit from a drop in its stock. The S.E.C. ended a related inquiry of Gradient last year and also declined to take action.

snippet: T-Mobile said Starbucks breached a contract by allowing AT&T to supply in-store customers with free wireless Internet access using T-Mobile’s lines and equipment.
lead_paragraph: T-Mobile USA sued Starbucks, saying the coffee chain breached a contract by allowing AT&T to supply in-store customers with free wireless Internet access using T-Mobile’s lines and equipment. T-Mobile, which said it agreed to provide Wi-Fi service at Starbucks in 2002, accused the largest American coffee chain of secretly developing a plan to let AT&T provide free Internet service at more than 7,000 Starbucks stores in the United States. T-Mobile said it is bearing the cost and burden of the free Wi-Fi service offer because it provided equipment and technology at thousands of Starbucks stores. Valerie O’Neil, a spokeswoman for Starbucks, did not return a voice-mail message left at her office seeking comment.

headline.main: T-Mobile Sues Starbucks Over Hot Spots

lead_paragraph: IN the six months since Bank of America announced its plans to take over Countrywide Financial, many investors have doubted that the $4 billion deal for the hobbled mortgage lender would get done. Bank of America has been strangely silent about its plans for merging the two operations, with the exception of a cryptic regulatory filing last month warning that investors should not count on it assuming all of Countrywide’s debt.

lead_paragraph: READY for some good news from your humble research assistant? abstract: An article on April 20, adapted from the book “The Big Squeeze: Tough Times for the American Worker,” referred imprecisely to the Internal Revenue Service’s treatment of FedEx Ground, the delivery business, over the way it classifies truck operators. The I.R.S. preliminarily assessed FedEx $319 million in taxes and penalties, plus interest, for 2002 over its classification of truck operators as independent contractors rather than employees; the I.R.S. did not order it to pay $319 million. As the article noted, the I.R.S. told FedEx that it could face similar charges for subsequent years.

lead_paragraph: Over the last 10 years, the average share of Americans listening to radio at any given time has shrunk about 14 percent, or 2.3 percentage points. Teenagers account for a well-recognized chunk of that decline. lead_paragraph: FARE INCREASE ROLLBACK Four major airlines all retreated on Monday from an across-the-board fare increase that United Airlines initiated over the weekend. Continental Airlines, American Airlines, Delta Airlines and United rescinded the increases, typically $20 on most round-trip tickets, which would have been the 17th fare increase this year. Neither Northwest Airlines nor US Airways had rescinded their increase on Monday, but they were expected to do so by Tuesday. The old-line carriers’ inability to make the latest fare increases stick “could be the first sign that demand is softening,” said Graeme Wallace, of the airfare tracker FareCompare.com

abstract: As we watch the housing bubble deflate, it almost produces nostalgia for the technology bubble with which we began this decade. It turned out consumers were not much affected by a stock market tumble, reflecting the fact that most people did not have a lot of stock, and so had not suffered really bad losses. The wealth effect of that bursting bubble was muted, at worst.
lead_paragraph: As we watch the housing bubble deflate, it almost produces nostalgia for the technology bubble with which we began this decade. It turned out consumers were not much affected by a stock market tumble, reflecting the fact that most people did not have a lot of stock, and so had not suffered really bad losses. The wealth effect of that bursting bubble was muted, at worst.

abstract: The author Maggie Jackson writes about the importance of focused attention in an era of constant interruptions and distractions.
snippet: The author Maggie Jackson writes about the importance of focused attention in an era of constant interruptions and distractions.
lead_paragraph: The subject of focus comes up a lot on this blog and in my discussions with people about work. We talk about the constant interruptions of working in the digital age, of the mistakes we make while multitasking, and the efforts to find quiet places to think. Maggie Jackson has been paying attention to these questions for quite some time, and the result is a thoughtful new book, “Distracted: The Erosion of Attention and the Coming Dark Age.”

headline.main: Attention Must Be Paid

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The National Transportation Safety Board on Tuesday identified sleepy pilots as a reason that a regional jet slid off a snowy runway in Traverse City, Mich., in April 2007, and the agency again called on the Federal Aviation Administration to take steps to manage fatigue.

headline.main: Safety Board Determines Pilot Fatigue Caused Skid
headline.print_headline: Safety Board Determines Pilot Fatigue Caused Skid

abstract: Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson said that the U.S.-China relationship is “growing in a positive direction,” but that he would press for a more open Chinese economy.
snippet: Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson said that the U.S.-China relationship is “growing in a positive direction,” but that he would press for a more open Chinese economy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Two years ago, Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. left Goldman Sachs and joined the Bush administration, hoping to use his expertise and contacts to ease economic tensions with China. His other goal was to stop Congress from passing legislation that might make tensions worse.

headline.main: Paulson’s Path to China: Progress, but Miles to Go
headline.print_headline: Paulson’s Path to China: Progress, but Miles to Go

abstract: Urban big-box retailing is no longer a novelty as more shopping centers try to squeeze into densely populated neighborhoods.

snippet: When the temperature soars, how skimpily can we — and should we — dress for work?
lead_paragraph: This past week I had plenty of moments where I reveled in the ability to work from home, mostly because it allowed me to save time worrying about what to wear during New York’s unexpected heat wave. The basic problem is that anything that made sense for being outside or underground in the subway would not be warm enough once I reached an air-conditioned destination. I probably could have written three blog posts in the time it took me to figure out what to wear to the few meetings I had outside my home office.

headline.main: Weather for Hoses, Not Hosiery

abstract: Staples agreed to buy Corporate Express for 1.68 billion euros ($2.6 billion) after raising its offer three times, becoming the world’s largest direct distributor of office supplies to companies.
snippet: Staples agreed to buy Corporate Express for 1.68 billion euros ($2.6 billion) after raising its offer three times, becoming the world’s largest direct distributor of office supplies to companies.
lead_paragraph: Staples agreed to buy Corporate Express for 1.68 billion euros ($2.6 billion) after raising its offer three times, becoming the world’s largest direct distributor of office supplies to companies. Staples, which has more than 2,000 stores, will get operations that ship office supplies to companies in Europe, the United States and Canada and add markets in Australia and New Zealand. Staples said it would pay 9.25 euros a share for Corporate Express. The bid was 28 percent more than Staples’s original offer made in February. The agreement scuttles a deal Corporate Express struck to acquire a French rival, Lyreco, last month.

headline.main: The Netherlands: Staples Sets Deal
headline.print_headline: The Netherlands: Staples Sets Deal

abstract: You can save paper by going to Word’s Print Preview in the File menu and clicking the “Shrink to Fit” or “Shrink One Page” button.
snippet: You can save paper by going to Word’s Print Preview in the File menu and clicking the “Shrink to Fit” or “Shrink One Page” button.
lead_paragraph: Hate those printed Word documents that have a few lines spilling over onto the last page? You can save paper by going to Word’s Print Preview in the File menu and clicking the “Shrink to Fit” or “Shrink One Page” button, which has an icon showing multiple pages transforming onto one page. Word will automatically fiddle with the document’s text size and spacing to get it all on a single page. But if the shrinkage messes up your formatting or looks too cramped, undo it by pressing Control-Z (Command-Z on a Mac), which reverses the process.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Thinking Green When You Print

lead_paragraph: Lots of people ask me why I left the law and I usually give them a few reasons, including the following: I went to law school mostly to please my parents; the idealism I’d felt as a law student waned when I saw how challenging it was to craft meaningful legal work that paid a living wage; I fell into a specialty that didn’t sustain my interest and found it easier to reinvent myself in a new career than within my existing one.

abstract: For five consecutive days, shares of Lehman Brothers have plodded lower. Which is hardly surprising, given the firm’s announcement Monday that it would report the first quarterly loss in its history as a public company, and the rampant speculation that it was vulnerable to a crisis in confidence similar to the one that felled Bear Stearns. On Thursday, as Lehman replaced its chief financial officer and chief operating officer, the firm’s chief executive, Richard Fuld Jr., told employees in a memo that “our credibility has eroded.”

abstract: UBS and the Credit Suisse Group, Switzerland’s two largest banks, agreed to pay almost 357 million euros ($548 million) to settle all legal claims related to their role in financing Parmalat.
snippet: UBS and the Credit Suisse Group, Switzerland’s two largest banks, agreed to pay almost 357 million euros ($548 million) to settle all legal claims related to their role in financing Parmalat.
lead_paragraph: UBS and the Credit Suisse Group, Switzerland’s two largest banks, agreed to pay almost 357 million euros ($548 million) to settle all legal claims related to their role in financing Parmalat, the dairy company that collapsed five years ago in Italy’s biggest bankruptcy. UBS will pay more than 184 million euros and Credit Suisse will pay 172.5 million euros, Parmalat said in separate statements on Friday. Parmalat’s chief executive, Enrico Bondi, filed lawsuits against dozens of Parmalat’s banks, contending they helped hide the true state of the company’s finances from investors. The banks did not acknowledge any wrongdoing.

headline.main: Two Swiss Banks Agree to Settlement in Parmalat Case
headline.print_headline: Two Swiss Banks Agree To Settlement In Parmalat Case

abstract: American financial markets have shown a “pronounced turnaround” since March, said Alan Greenspan, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve.
snippet: American financial markets have shown a “pronounced turnaround” since March, said Alan Greenspan, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve.
lead_paragraph: American financial markets, roiled by the collapse of the subprime-mortgage market, have shown a “pronounced turnaround” since March, Alan Greenspan, former chairman of the Federal Reserve, said Friday. The worst is over for the credit crisis, or will be soon, and there is now a “reduced possibility” of a deep recession, Mr. Greenspan said in remarks via satellite to a conference in Mexico City. His remarks echo the assessment of the Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, who said this week that danger of a “substantial downturn” in the economy had receded.  Still, the persistent slump in the housing market is putting ”major downward pressure” on the economy, said Greenspan, who served as Fed chairman from August 1987 to January 2006.

headline.main: Greenspan Sees Light at the End of the Credit Tunnel
headline.print_headline: Greenspan Sees Light at the End of the Credit Tunnel

abstract: The role of the Federal Reserve is different depending on the type of economic bubble it faces.
snippet: The role of the Federal Reserve is different depending on the type of economic bubble it faces.
lead_paragraph: LATELY more and more people have been questioning the received wisdom about what a central bank should do when confronted by an asset price bubble. That piece of wisdom, shared by Alan Greenspan and Ben S. Bernanke, the former and present Federal Reserve chairmen, holds that deliberate bubble-bursting is something between impossible and dangerous  and thus best avoided. Instead, according to this view, the Fed should let bubbles burst of their own accord, and then be prepared to mop up after.

headline.main: Two Bubbles, Two Paths

abstract: Restricting award recipients to five-word acceptance speeches leads to some examples of smart branding.
snippet: Restricting award recipients to five-word acceptance speeches leads to some examples of smart branding.
lead_paragraph: The Webby Awards, honoring excellence on the Internet, were announced last week. And after I recovered from not being nominated, I spent some time browsing the list of acceptance speeches, which adhered to an interesting format. The winners had to accept their awards using no more than five words. The most successful of these speeches are terrific examples of branding. For example, Stephen Colbert, the winner of the Webby person of the year award, simply accepted with “Me. Me. Me. Me. Me.”

headline.main: Five Words to Communicate Brand

lead_paragraph: There was a lot of anger in the blogosphere last week over The Associated Press’s assertion that some blogs were infringing its copyright by publishing excerpts of its articles. When I finally reached Jim Kennedy, an Associated Press vice president, he told me that the news agency now feels its demand was heavy-handed and was rethinking its policies. I wrote about this in Monday’s Times.

abstract: To deal with the hassle of getting visas stamped in their employees’ passports, businesses are increasingly outsourcing the task to companies known as expediters.

lead_paragraph: For business travelers headed overseas, getting a visa, when required, can be the worst part of the trip. It requires filling out forms, surrendering your passport for a few days or a week and paying a fee that can seem exorbitant, sometimes only with cash or a money order. For a multicountry itinerary, the time lag to get all the visas approved can take a month.

That compares with rivals like Lehman Brothers, which lost billions during the same period.

abstract: Woolworths Group, the British retailer, said its chief executive, Trevor Bish-Jones, would leave after six years in the position.

lead_paragraph: Woolworths Group, the British retailer, said its chief executive, Trevor Bish-Jones, would leave after six years in the position. The timing of the departure was the board’s decision, the chairman, Richard North, said during a conference call. Woolworths also reported a decline in sales and announced the sale of four stores for £25.5 million ($49.8 million). Sales have fallen for four consecutive years at Woolworths stores open at least 12 months. Mr. Bish-Jones, left, will stay in his post for three months while a successor is sought, Woolworths said.

headline.main: Britain: Chief Out at Woolworths

abstract: LinkedIn, a Web site that professionals use to make contacts and trade tips, created quite a stir this week. It announced that it raised $53 million in funding, primarily from Bain Capital Ventures, implicitly valuing the four-year-old company at an impressive $1 billion. It was only the latest evidence that social networks for the more-serious set — think Facebook, as opposed to a more youth-oriented MySpace — have come into vogue with investors.

abstract: In a fight with a social news site, The Associated Press has asserted that Internet sites cannot quote the headline and first paragraph of its articles. But so far, the news organization hasn’t articulated its own guidelines for its view of how Web sites can use its content.
snippet: In a fight with a social news site, The Associated Press has asserted that Internet sites cannot quote the headline and first paragraph of its articles. But so far, the news organization hasn’t articulated its own guidelines for its view of how We...
lead_paragraph: The Associated Press has punted on its commitment to clarify how much text it thinks bloggers and social news sites can reprint from its articles without violating The AP’s copyright. Indeed, the giant news organization appears to be insisting that bloggers cannot quote the headline of an A.P. story or its first paragraph. While the law is not settled, many lawyers suggest that such short excerpts are permitted under the “fair use” exception to the copyright laws.

headline.main: The A.P. Asserts Tough (and Still Secret) View of Copyright on Blogs

abstract: Michael Cohl, chairman of Live Nation, the world’s largest concert promoter, stepped down Friday after a report of a strategy dispute with the chief executive, Michael Rapino.
snippet: Michael Cohl, chairman of Live Nation, the world’s largest concert promoter, stepped down Friday after a report of a strategy dispute with the chief executive, Michael Rapino.
lead_paragraph: Michael Cohl, chairman of Live Nation, the world’s largest concert promoter, stepped down Friday after a report of a strategy dispute with the chief executive, Michael Rapino. Mr. Cohl, who had held the post since February, will become a consultant to the company, based in Beverly Hills, Calif. Mr. Cohl, 60, joined the company’s board in 2006 after Live Nation bought a controlling stake in Concert Productions International, which he founded.

headline.main: Live Nation Chairman Will Step Down
headline.print_headline: Live Nation Chairman Will Step Down

abstract: Boeing said that tests on the 787 Dreamliner’s power systems were successful, putting the plane on schedule for its initial flight in the fourth quarter and delivery to customers next year.
snippet: Boeing said that tests on the 787 Dreamliner’s power systems were successful, putting the plane on schedule for its initial flight in the fourth quarter and delivery to customers next year.
lead_paragraph: Boeing said that tests on the 787 Dreamliner’s power systems were successful, putting the plane on schedule for its initial flight in the fourth quarter and delivery to customers next year. The Dreamliner’s reliance on electricity, along with lighter-weight composite materials and new technology, will reduce fuel consumption by 20 percent from comparable planes in service now. The electrical system on the 787, which has power levels five times higher than on Boeing’s 767, is largely independent of the jet engines, reducing fuel usage because power isn’t being bled away to run lights and other systems.

headline.main: Boeing’s Dreamliner Passes a Crucial Test
headline.print_headline: Boeing’s Dreamliner Passes a Crucial Test

lead_paragraph: Mexico’s peso closed at its strongest level against the dollar in five years Friday after the Bank of Mexico raised its benchmark interest rate, citing higher inflation. The currency was quoted in Mexico City closing at 10.275 pesos to the dollar, compared with 10.3185 at the open and Thursday’s close of 10.3120. The Bank of Mexico raised the overnight rate to 7.75 percent, from 7.5 percent, in its first monetary policy move since last October.

lead_paragraph: IN 1995, home prices in the United States rose by 1.7 percent. They kept climbing over the next 10 years at an accelerating rate. The climax was in 2005, when the increase was 15.7 percent, putting home prices at more than double their 1995 level. Except for the early years after World War II and during the great inflation of the 1970s, home prices in the United States had never doubled in the short space of 10 years.

As he kicked into “The Righteous Path,” a song from the group’s new-ish record “Brighter Than Creation’s Dark,” it was if the space in front of him was filled with sunburned bobble-heads, each bouncing in unison to every word: “Trying to hold steady on the righteous path, 80 miles an hour with a worn-out map.”

abstract: News about airlines and airports.
snippet: News about airlines and airports.
lead_paragraph: UNITED ADDS MINIMUM STAY RULES  United Airlines says it will put minimum stay restrictions on almost all its coach fares, for travel starting Oct. 6. The move comes two months after United said it would add Saturday night stay requirements on 65 percent of its routes, and as other airlines are generally reintroducing minimum stay and Saturday night stay rules that were largely discarded in 2001 because of competition from low-cost airlines. In general, said a United spokeswoman, Robin Urbanski, the lower the fare, the higher the minimum stay requirement. For some of the lowest fares in some markets, a combined Saturday and Sunday night stay will be required. Minimum stay requirements have generally been used by airlines to discourage business travelers from buying the cheapest fares.

abstract: The WPP Group, an advertising company, said sales growth slowed in the first five months of the year as business in Western Europe continued to lag behind other regions.
snippet: The WPP Group, an advertising company, said sales growth slowed in the first five months of the year as business in Western Europe continued to lag behind other regions.
lead_paragraph: The WPP Group, an advertising company, said sales growth slowed in the first five months of the year as business in Western Europe continued to lag behind other regions. Sales excluding acquisitions and currency swings climbed 4.5 percent, WPP said. On that basis a year earlier, sales grew 5.2 percent, the company said at the time. Advertising spending in Western Europe has been hurt as soaring energy prices sapped households’ buying power and companies lowered marketing expenses. WPP said sales in Continental Europe had grown less than in Asia, Latin America, Africa and Eastern Europe. Stock in WPP, which is based in London, fell 3.7 percent.

headline.main: Britain: Ad Company’s Sales Growth Slows

abstract: The report today is that Anheuser Busch is going to reject the InBev offer. InBev will now have to decide whether it will launch a consent solicitation to remove all of the Anheuser directors. This can be done at any time. Alternatively, at the request of 25% of Anheuser’s shareholders a special meeting of Anheuser shareholders can be held. So, InBev can also go this route and remove the Anheuser directors at the special meeting if they can get enough shareholder support for it to be called. I suspect that if InBev does attempt to remove and replace the Anheuser directors, InBev will arrange a consent solicitation rather than attempting to call a special meeting: it is quicker.
lead_paragraph: The report today is that Anheuser Busch is going to reject the InBev offer. InBev will now have to decide whether it will launch a consent solicitation to remove all of the Anheuser directors. This can be done at any time. Alternatively, at the request of 25% of Anheuser’s shareholders a special meeting of Anheuser shareholders can be held. So, InBev can also go this route and remove the Anheuser directors at the special meeting if they can get enough shareholder support for it to be called. I suspect that if InBev does attempt to remove and replace the Anheuser directors, InBev will arrange a consent solicitation rather than attempting to call a special meeting: it is quicker.

headline.main: Some Questions About Those Commitment Letters

lead_paragraph: Fitch Ratings may lower the credit ratings of Wachovia, the bank that ousted its chief executive after greater-than-expected mortgage losses. In a report Friday, Fitch said that Wachovia, based in Charlotte, N.C., increased its loan loss reserve by $2 billion as of March 31, which represented “only about 1.2 percent” of the bank’s $170 billion mortgage portfolio. About 70 percent of Wachovia’s mortgages are option adjustable-rate mortgages that let borrowers skip part of their payment and add the sum to their principal. The company declined to comment.

headline.main: Fitch Weighs Lower Rating for Wachovia
headline.print_headline: Fitch Weighs Lower Rating For Wachovia

lead_paragraph: Hollywood is having a good-to-great summer. Box office is marginally up  mostly on the strength of increased ticket prices, but still, there’s over $4.52 billion already in the bank this year, according to Media by Numbers. The big studios  the sworn enemy of moviegoing snobs  have used great casting, like Robert Downey Jr. in “Iron Man,” Steve Carell in “Get Smart,” filmmaking innovation in Pixar’s “Wall-E” and “Wanted” and smart retreading in “Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull” and “Sex and the City” to leave both audiences and the people in the studio corner office happy.

abstract: While food companies have reduced portion sizes to respond to concerns about overeating, a new study shows that small packages can also lead to over-consumption.
snippet: While food companies have reduced portion sizes to respond to concerns about overeating, a new study shows that small packages can also lead to over-consumption.
lead_paragraph: It is a truism of public health that people consume more junk food from large packages than from small ones. In response, food companies have decreased portion sizes and introduced single-serve packages, particularly for foods like ice cream and snack chips that people have usually bought in bulk, deciding on their own what constitutes a proper portion.

headline.main: Overindulgence in Small Packages
headline.print_headline: Overindulgence in Small Packages
